case_name: Messrs Bhatnagars Co. Private Ltd. v. Sea Customs Authorities

facts.text: Group of five petitions filed under Article 32: Nos. 377 of 1955, 42, 46, 164 and 423 of 1956 by Messrs Bhatnagars Co. Private Ltd., petitioner Shri B. S. Bhatnagar.

anchor.surface_text: This is a group of five petitions filed by the petitioners Messrs Bhatnagars Co. Private Ltd. In all these petitions, the petitioner Shri B. S. Bhatnagar, Managing Director of the above companypany, seeks to obtain appropriate writs from this Court mainly in respect of orders which have been passed by the Sea Customs Authorities against the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner obtained a licence for the import of soda ash worth about Rs. 50,00,000 during the free licensing period in 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the petitioner obtained a licence for the import of soda ash only worth about Rs. 50,00,000 during the free licensing period in 1952. In pursuance of this licence, and relying on the same, companysignments of soda ash to the extent of 100 tons, 200 tons and 20 tons respectively were received at Bombay but meanwhile the Customs Authorities had received information that, though the petitioner had obtained a licence in his name for the import of soda ash for such a large amount as Rs. 50,00,000, his capital did number exceed Rs. 15,000 and that he was in fact trafficking in these licences.

facts.text: Consignments of soda ash: 100 tons, 200 tons, and 20 tons received at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this licence, and relying on the same, companysignments of soda ash to the extent of 100 tons, 200 tons and 20 tons respectively were received at Bombay but meanwhile the Customs Authorities had received information that, though the petitioner had obtained a licence in his name for the import of soda ash for such a large amount as Rs. 50,00,000, his capital did number exceed Rs. 15,000 and that he was in fact trafficking in these licences.

facts.text: Customs Authorities received information that petitioner's capital did not exceed Rs. 15,000 and he was trafficking in licences.

anchor.surface_text: but meanwhile the Customs Authorities had received information that, though the petitioner had obtained a licence in his name for the import of soda ash for such a large amount as Rs. 50,00,000, his capital did number exceed Rs. 15,000 and that he was in fact trafficking in these licences. On receiving this report, investigation was made and subsequently the matter was left in charge of the Special Police Establishment.

facts.text: Investigation conducted by Special Police Establishment; documents seized from petitioner's office and Messrs N. Jivanlal Co. at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving this report, investigation was made and subsequently the matter was left in charge of the Special Police Establishment. During the companyrse of this investigation, certain documents were seized from the petitioner-companys office as well as from the office of one Messrs N. Jivanlal Co. at Bombay.

facts.text: Investigation confirmed complaint of licence trafficking; N. Jivanlal Co. had free hand in dealing with petitioner's licences; petitioner received commission.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplaint made against the petitioner that he was trafficking in licences was companyfirmed by this investigation. It transpired that a person carrying on business in the name of Messrs. N. Jivanlal Co., had a free hand in dealing with the licences of the petitioner and that the petitioner used only to receive companymission for the imports that he allowed to be made in the name of Messrs Bhatnagars Co., Ltd.

facts.text: 100 tons and 20 tons consignments imported by N. Jivanlal Co., who held no licence; seized by Collector of Customs.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the two companysignments of 100 tons and 20 tons of soda ash respectively, it was found on an inspection of the documents that the same had been imported by Messrs N. Jivanlal Co., and since Messrs N. Jivanlal Co., held numberlicence, the companysignments were seized by the Collector of Customs.

facts.text: Raids: petitioner's office on November 7, 1952; N. Jivanlal Co. office on February 6, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The offices of the petitioner and Messrs N. Jivanlal Co., were raided during the companyrse of this investigation on November 7,1952 and February 6, 1953, respectively.

facts.text: Goods arrived in Bombay in March and April 1953; confiscated by Collector of Customs in May and June 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The goods arrived in Bombay in March and April 1953 and they were companyfiscated by the Collector of Customs in May and June 1953.

facts.text: Seized documents including licences returned to petitioner subsequently.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the documents including the licences which had been seized were returned to the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner appealed confiscation to Central Board of Revenue; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The companyfiscation of the goods was challenged by the petitioner by preferring an appeal to the Central Board of Revenue. The said appeal was, however, dismissed.

facts.text: Petitioner moved Central Government in revision; refused to interfere on September 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then moved the Central Government against this, order but on September 22, 1955, the Central Government refused to interfere.

facts.text: On March 31, 1956, Collector of Customs ordered goods auctioned; petitioner filed petition and obtained interim stay, later vacated.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on March 31, 1956, the Collector of Customs ordered that the goods should be auctioned. When this order was passed, the petitioner filed one of the petitions before us. - He obtained an interim order of stay but the said order was ultimately vacated.

facts.text: Earlier petition No. 571 of 1954 regarding one consignment; heard March 24, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner had made a similar petition to this Court, No. 571 of 1954, in respect of one of the three companysignments, in question. This petition had companye before this Court for hearing on March 24, 1955.

facts.text: Solicitor-General undertook goods not to be sold for one month after communication of Central Government's final order on revision.

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by this Court would show that the learned Solicitor-General of India made a statement to the Court indicating that the goods which had been companyfiscated by the Customs Authorities would number be, sold or otherwise dealt with for a month from the date of the companymunication to the petitioner of the final order that the Central Government may pass in the revisional petition preferred by him before them.

facts.text: Press Note dated February 3, 1955 on import policy for soda ash.

anchor.surface_text: In Petition No. 164 of 1956, so far as we were able to gather, the petitioners grievance is in respect of a policy statement made by the Government in the Press Note dated February 3, 1955 and Public Notice No. 25-ITC  PN  56 dated June 30, 1956.

facts.text: Public Notice No. 25-ITC PN 56 dated June 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: the petitioners grievance is in respect of a policy statement made by the Government in the Press Note dated February 3, 1955 and Public Notice No. 25-ITC  PN  56 dated June 30, 1956.

facts.text: Order dated May 3, 1954 by Controller of Imports and Exports: no licence or clearance up to July 1953; no revalidation of licences in Annexure A.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the order dated May 3, 1954, has been passed by the Controller of Imports and Exports for Chief Controller of Imports and Exports and it companymunicates to the petitioner the decision of the Chief Controller that numberlicence or customs clearance permit would be granted to him against his application for and upto the licensing period July 1953.

facts.text: Licences granted to petitioner alive for one year from February 13, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners case is that, since he was granted licences which were to be alive for one year from February 13, 1952, the illegal seizure of the licence and the unauthorised companyfiscation of the companysignments in question caused companysiderable. prejudice to him.

facts.text: Petition No. 377 of 1955 argued by petitioner in person.

anchor.surface_text: Three of the petitions have been argued by Shri Bhatnagar in person. They are Petitions Nos. 423 and 164 of 1956 and No. 377 of 1955.

facts.text: Petitions Nos. 42 and 46 of 1956 argued by J. Umrigar.

anchor.surface_text: Petitions Nos. 42 and 46 of 1956 have been argued by Shri Umrigar on behalf of the petitioner.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 21, 1957 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. February 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-This is a group of five petitions filed by the petitioners Messrs Bhatnagars Co. Private Ltd.

facts.text: Prior to 1953, import licences freely granted; in 1953, to established importers with conditions.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that, prior to 1953, import licences were freely granted. In 1953, licences began to be granted to established importers subject to certain companyditions.

facts.text: Petitioner not an established importer; granted licence during free period.

anchor.surface_text: It is also important to emphasize that the petitioner is number even an established importer. He was granted a licence during the free period, and so it is difficult to understand his grievance that a monopoly had been created

facts.text: All petitions dismissed with costs.

issues.text: Whether the Union of India and other respondents acted in contempt of this Court by violating the Solicitor-General's undertaking regarding disposal of the revisional petition?

anchor.surface_text: the substantial relief which he seeks to claim and which the petitioner pressed before us in his argument is in respect of his allegation that the Union of India and other respondents to the petition have acted in contempt of this Court

issues.text: Whether the policy of canalisation of soda ash imports through specified importer-stockists creates a monopoly violating the petitioner's fundamental right to carry on trade under Article 19?

anchor.surface_text: the petitioners contention appears to be that the policy enunciated in these two documents amounts to a monopoly and he wants this Court to issue appropriate writs terminating this monopoly and to ensure to the petitioner his fundamental right of carrying on his trade and business.

issues.text: Whether this Court has jurisdiction under Article 32 to direct revalidation of expired import licences or grant relief against factual findings of licence trafficking and confiscation?

anchor.surface_text: difficult to understand how the petitioner can invoke the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution for obtaining this relief.

issues.text: Whether a licence was required for the import of soda ash under the Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947, given the omission of certain provisions from the Defence of India Rules?

anchor.surface_text: He contends that the Import-Export Act does not apply to soda ash and that it is every citizens right to import and export this commodity without a licence.

issues.text: Whether Section 3 of the Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947 constitutes invalid delegated legislation lacking policy guidance?

anchor.surface_text: the legislation which authorises the issue of licences amounts to a delegated legislation and as such is invalid.

issues.text: Whether the authorities' finding that the petitioner was trafficking in licences and that the consignments belonged to another party was based on no legal evidence?
Whether the petitions are maintainable under Article 32 to challenge factual conclusions of customs authorities regarding confiscation?

arguments.claim: Court should direct revalidation of expired licences due to illegal seizure and confiscation causing prejudice; jurisdiction under Art 32.

arguments.claim: No jurisdiction under Art 32 to challenge factual findings of customs authorities on confiscation.

anchor.surface_text: Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights... since the petitions purport to invoke the jurisdiction of this Court substantially under Art. 32 of the Constitution, it is necessary

holdings.text: We have no hesitation in holding that the prayer for a writ in respect of the alleged contempt made by the petitioner in this petition is thoroughly unjustified and, we regret to add, wholly irresponsible.

anchor.surface_text: We have no hesitation in holding that the prayer for a writ in respect of the alleged contempt made by the petitioner in this petition is thoroughly unjustified and, we regret to add, wholly irresponsible. This was the only point, which the petitioner urged before us in this petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Solicitor-General's undertaking was only not to sell goods for one month after communication of Central Government's order on revision to allow time for special leave petition; no undertaking to decide revision timely; order plain and unambiguous; no violation.

holdings.text: In substance no monopoly has been created and the petitioners application is entirely misconceived.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, it is difficult to entertain the argument from the present petitioner that the alleged monopoly has affected his right to carry on trade. In substance no monopoly has been created and the petitioners application is entirely misconceived. The result is the petition fails and must be dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Canalisation through stockists ensures even distribution, buffer stocks, price stability; reasonable regulation in national interest; petitioner not established importer; no deprivation of Art 19(1)(g) right.

holdings.text: But it is difficult to understand how the petitioner can invoke the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution for obtaining this relief.

anchor.surface_text: But it is difficult to understand how the petitioner can invoke the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution for obtaining this relief. We do not propose to discuss this matter elaborately because, in our opinion, the position in law is abundantly clear.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 32 not for challenging factual findings on trafficking/confiscation or directing revalidation of expired licences; grievance against factual conclusions; alternative remedy by suit for damages.

holdings.text: We must, therefore, hold that the argument that no licence was required for the import of soda ash and so all the orders passed by the appropriate authorities in regard to the confiscation of the consignments are invalid must fail.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the argument that no licence was required for the import of soda ash and so all the orders passed by the appropriate authorities in regard to the confiscation of the consignments are invalid must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.3(1)(a) Imports Act applies disjunctively to import of specified goods like soda ash; omission of r.84(2) Defence of India Rules unnecessary as covered; s.19 Sea Customs deems prohibited/restricted.

holdings.text: Unfortunately for Shri Umrigar his challenge to the validity of the impugned section under the Imports and Exports Act is completely covered by the decision of this Court in Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Unfortunately for Shri Umrigar his challenge to the validity of the impugned section under the Imports and Exports Act is completely covered by the decision of this Court in Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh. In this case, ss. 3 and 4 of the Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946, were attacked as ultra vires on the ground of delegated legislation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preamble and predecessor Defence of India Act provide policy of maintaining essential supplies/public interest; follows Harishankar Bagla and Pannalal Binjraj precedents; sufficient guidance to delegate.

holdings.text: In the present case, it is impossible to accede to the assumption that there is no legal evidence against the petitioner.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal evidence exists: low capital, conduct, N. Jivanlal's role, false allegations; concurrent findings by authorities; not reviewable under Art 32.

holdings.text: Since the petitions purport to invoke the jurisdiction of this Court substantially under Art. 32 of the Constitution, it is necessary to deal with the relevant points in disposing of these petitions.

anchor.surface_text: However, since the petitions purport to invoke the jurisdiction of this Court substantially under Art. 32 of the Constitution, it is necessary to deal with the relevant points in disposing of these petitions. Three of the petitions have been argued by Shri Bhatnagar in person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 32 jurisdiction limited; cannot review factual determinations or administrative decisions on licences/confiscation; petitions challenge facts, not fundamental rights.
